description: Borrowed from Middle French occasion, from Old French occasiun, from Latin occasiōnem, noun of action from perfect passive participle occasus, from verb occido, from prefix ob- (“down", "away”) + verb cado (“fall”).

entries.meaning: A favorable opportunity; a convenient or timely chance. [from 14th c.]
examples: At this point, she seized the occasion to make her own observation.
on this occasion, I'm going to decline your offer, but next time I might agree.

entries.meaning: An occurrence or state of affairs which causes some event or reaction; a motive or reason. [from 14th c.]
examples: I had no occasion to feel offended, however.

entries.meaning: Something which causes something else; a cause. [from 14th c.]
examples: it were too vile to say, and scarce to be beleeved, what we endured: but the occasion was our owne, for want of providence, industrie and government [...].

entries.meaning: A particular happening; an instance or time when something occurred. [from 15th c.]
examples: I could think of two separate occasions when she had deliberately lied to me.
a momentous occasion in the history of South Africa
I have no occasion for firearms.

entries.meaning: A special event or function. [from 19th c.]
examples: Having people round for dinner was always quite an occasion at our house.

entries.meaning: A reason or excuse; a motive; a persuasion.

verbs.description: occasion (third-person singular simple present occasions, present participle occasioning, simple past and past participle occasioned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause; to produce; to induce
examples: it is seen that the mental changes are occasioned by a change of polarity
